com.martinandersson.javaee.jpa.entitymanagers.applicationmanaged

Class JTATest

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.martinandersson.javaee.jpa.entitymanagers.AbstractJTAEntityManagerTest
      • com.martinandersson.javaee.jpa.entitymanagers.applicationmanaged.JTATest

  • public class JTATest
extends AbstractJTAEntityManagerTest
    The life cycle of an application-managed entity manager is managed by the application/bean.

    The entity manager may use JTA transactions or resource-local transactions1.

    The persistence context of an application managed entity manager

    JPA 2.1, section "7.7 Application-managed Persistence Contexts": 
    
 
     All such application-managed persistence contexts are extended in scope,
     and can span multiple transactions.
     
     [..]
 
     An extended persistence context obtained from the application-managed
     entity manager is a stand-alone persistence context - it is not
     propagated with the transaction.
    JPA 2.1, section "7.1 Persistence Context" makes it clear what exactly a stand-alone context is: 
    
 
     [..] each instance of creating an entity manager causes a new isolated
     persistence context to be created that is not accessible through other
     EntityManager references within the same transaction.

    Controlling the life cycle

    JPA 2.1, section "7.7 Application-managed Persistence Contexts" 
    
 
     The EntityManagerFactory.createEntityManager method and the EntityManager
     close and isOpen methods are used to manage the lifecycle of an
     application-managed entity manager and its associated persistence
     context.
 
     The extended persistence context exists from the point at which the
     entity manager has been created using
     EntityManagerFactory.createEntityManager until the entity manager is
     closed by means of EntityManager.close.
 
     [..]
 
     The EntityManager.close method closes an entity manager to release its
     persistence context and other resources. After calling close, the
     application must not invoke any further methods on the EntityManager
     instance except for getTransaction and isOpen, or the
     IllegalStateException will be thrown. If the close method is invoked when
     a transaction is active, the persistence context remains managed until
     the transaction completes.
    JPA 2.1, section "7.9.2 Provider Responsibilities": 
    
 
     When EntityManagerFactory.setupEntityManager is invoked, the provider
     must create and return a new entity manager.

    The entity manager can only auto join a transaction that is in scope

    JPA 2.1, section "7.7 Application-managed Persistence Contexts" 
    
 
     When a JTA application-managed entity manager is used, if the entity
     manager is created outside the scope of the current JTA transaction, it
     is the responsibility of the application to join the entity manager to
     the transaction (if desired) by calling EntityManager.joinTransaction.
     If the entity manager is created outside the scope of a JTA transaction,
     it is not joined to the transaction unless EntityManager.joinTransaction
     is called.

    Note 1

    For more info regarding resource-local transactions, see ResourceLocalTest.
    Author:
    Martin Andersson (webmaster at martinandersson.com)

      • normalUse_createdInsideTransaction

        public void normalUse_createdInsideTransaction()
        Create a new entity manager within the scope of an active JTA transaction, do persist a new product and expect success.

      • normalUse_createdOutsideTransaction

        public void normalUse_createdOutsideTransaction()
        Create a new entity manager without having a transaction active, then create a transaction and hook up entity manager.

        We expect that persisting a new product is a no-brainer.

      • mustNotUseClosedEntityManager

        public void mustNotUseClosedEntityManager()

      • entitiesManagedAfterEMClosedIfTransactionWasNotCompleted

        public void entitiesManagedAfterEMClosedIfTransactionWasNotCompleted()
        JPA 2.1, section "7.7 Application-managed Persistence Contexts": 
        
 
     If the close method is invoked when a transaction is active, the
     persistence context remains managed until the transaction completes.

      • noTransactionNoFlush_changesLost

        public void noTransactionNoFlush_changesLost()
        Create entity manager before having a transaction started, persist.

        This is legal because the persistence context is extended. But without a transaction, entities are not saved/flushed to database and we loose our work.

      • standAlonePersistenceContextDoesNotInherit_transactional

        public void standAlonePersistenceContextDoesNotInherit_transactional()
                                                              throws NamingException
        The stand-alone persistence context of an application-managed entity manager may join an inbound transaction, but it does not inherit the previously associated persistence context.

        This test shows that it is true when going from a container-managed entity manager that uses a transaction-scoped persistence context.

        Throws:
        NamingException - on JNDI lookup failure

      • standAlonePersistenceContextDoesNotInherit_extended

        public void standAlonePersistenceContextDoesNotInherit_extended()
                                                         throws NamingException
        The stand-alone persistence context of an application-managed entity manager may join an inbound transaction, but it does not inherit the previously associated persistence context.

        This test shows that it is true when going from a container-managed entity manager that uses an extended persistence context.

        Throws:
        NamingException - on JNDI lookup failure

      • standAlonePersistenceContextNotPropagated_joined

        public void standAlonePersistenceContextNotPropagated_joined()
                                                      throws NamingException
        The persistence context of an application-managed entity manager is "stand-alone", meaning it is not propagated anywhere.

        This test start a transaction before making a call to a transactional bean that uses a transaction-scoped entity manager. The persistence context is not propagated.

        TODO: When resource-local test class is done, then move this type of common tests to a shared superclass, something like "AbstractApplicationManagedEntityManagerTest".

        Throws:
        NamingException - on JNDI lookup failure

      • standAlonePersistenceContextNotPropagated_notJoined

        public void standAlonePersistenceContextNotPropagated_notJoined()
                                                         throws NamingException
        The persistence context of an application-managed entity manager is "stand-alone", meaning it is not propagated anywhere.

        This test is a variant of standAlonePersistenceContextNotPropagated_joined() but uses no transaction before making same bean call. The persistence context is not propagated.

        Throws:
        NamingException - on JNDI lookup failure

      • getBeanBeingTested

        protected final EntityManagerExposer getBeanBeingTested()
        Description copied from class: AbstractJTAEntityManagerTest
        Returns the target bean that offer an exposed EntityManager.

        One must not assume anything about the state of the entity manager's persistence context after this method has been called.

        Specified by:
        getBeanBeingTested in class AbstractJTAEntityManagerTest
        Returns:
        the target bean that offer an exposed EntityManager
